text:

We will never share your email address. Nawar al-Awlaki (Nora): 5 Fast Facts You Need to Know Published Updated 7:56 pm EDT, February 1, 2017 3 Comments By Jessica McBride 9.2k Share Tweet Follow 
An 8-year-old American girl was reportedly killed in Donald Trumpâ€™s first approved clandestine operation against Al-Qaeda in Yemen, according to NBC News. 
Nawar al-Awlaki, sometimes called Nora, the daughter of an American-born Al-Qaeda leader assassinated by the United States several years ago, was slain in the U.S. operation that also killed a Navy Seal, the network reported. 
Other news organizations had attributed claims of the girlâ€™s death to her grandfather. NBC News reported that a â€œsenior military officialâ€ the network did not name had confirmed the childâ€™s death. The New York Times reported that U.S. officials denied there were civilian casualties but then said they were â€œassessing reports that women and childrenâ€ had died. 
Also killed in the raid targeting Al-Qaeda militants was American Chief Petty Officer William â€œRyanâ€ Owens. He was a member of the famed SEAL Team 6. Owens was the first U.S. combat death under President Trump. 
Heavy asked the Department of Defense, â€œIs it true that another American citizen died in that incident also? Who? And what age? Is it true that an 8-year-old American citizen, Nawar al-Alwaki, was killed in the incident? Was she killed by the Americans, Al-Qaeda or in another manner? How did she die?â€ 
Christopher Sherwood, a Department of Defense spokesman, responded, â€œWe take all civilian casualty reports seriously. As is CENTCOMâ€™s policy, they are looking into the civilian casualty claims and will make a determination on if there needs to be a full investigation.â€ 
The military has now released a statement saying that itâ€™s likely civilian casualties resulted from the raid, including possibly children. BREAKING: @CENTCOM says civilians were likely killed during Navy SEAL raid in Yemen on Jan. 29. "Casualties may include children." pic.twitter.com/WOK6ohGUz6 
â€” W.J. Hennigan (@wjhenn) February 2, 2017 
The childâ€™s father, Anwar al-Awlaki, was born in New Mexico but became a high-profile leader of Al-Qaeda. 
Hereâ€™s what you need to know: 1. Nawarâ€™s Father & Teenage Brother Were Previously Killed by the Americans 
The childâ€™s grandfather claimed that she â€œwas hit with a bullet in her neck and suffered for two hours,â€ according to the Christian Science Monitor. 
The grandfather, Nasser al-Awlaki, told Reuters: â€œWhy kill children? This is the new (US) administration â€“ itâ€™s very sad, a big crime.â€ 
The United States, upon the order of President Barack Obama, killed the girlâ€™s father with a drone in 2011. Her father, Anwar al-Awlaki, was a New Mexico born cleric who was the top Al-Qaeda leader in Yemen, according to The New York Times. The Times reported that his brother-in-law, also an Al-Qaeda leader, was believed killed in the recent raid. 
Nawarâ€™s 16-year-old brother, Abdulrahman al-Awlaki, also an American citizen, was then killed in another drone strike also authorized by Obama, according to the Atlantic. 
The recent operation was planned for months, before Trump took office, but he authorized it, according to KTLA. 
The Times reported that a Yemeni official contends seven children died in the recent raid, but this was not confirmed. 2. The Raid Was Supposed to Obtain Intelligence, Such as Computer Equipment, but Things â€˜Went Wrongâ€™ (Getty) 
The raid was targeting a powerful family associated with Al-Qaeda terrorist, Abdulraoof al-Dhahab. KTLA reported that the raid was â€œagainst al-Qaida in the Arabian Peninsula headquarters.â€ According to The New York Times, a â€œfierce firefightâ€ erupted in the raid, which was part of the â€œyearslong shadow war against Al-Qaedaâ€™s â€œYemen affiliate.â€ 
The Times reported that the goal was to obtain computer planning intelligence of plots against America in the targeted Al-Qaeda home. 
â€œAlmost everything went wrong,â€ NBC News quoted the unnamed official of the botched raid, which was overshadowed by the protests and controversies over Trumpâ€™s immigration ban. 
According to Reuters , accounts of the dead and injured conflicted. 
The U.S. military claimed 14 militants were killed, but medics present â€œsaid around 30 people, including 10 women and children, were killed,â€ Reuters reported. 
At least two other U.S. service members were injured, and a military aircraft had to be purposely destroyed, Reuters reported. 3. Owens, Killed During a Firefight on the Ground, Was a Decorated SEAL ğŸ‡ºğŸ‡¸ Navy SEAL killed in a raid on Al Qaeda identified as Chief Petty Officer William â€œRyanâ€ Owen https://t.co/lw2cypnAkE ğŸ‘ˆ see here ğŸ‡ºğŸ‡¸ pic.twitter.com/0x84gyqjKN 
â€” American Girl Thinks (@usa_news_24) January 31, 2017 
Owens, 36, of Peoria, Illinois, was a â€œdecorated Navy SEAL from the Virginia-based elite unit known as SEAL Team 6,â€ according to the San Diego Union Tribune . 
The newspaper said the SEAL â€œwas twice awarded the Bronze Star medal with V for valor in combat.â€ According to the Union-Tribune, Al-Qaeda women were among the fighters the SEALS faced. 
The gun battle that killed Owens lasted for two hours, reported the San Diego Union-Tribune. Trump and his daughter, Ivanka, went to meet Owensâ€™ body as he arrived back on American soil. You can read more about Owens here:
